# The ;masdar;

;wip_warn;

## Introduction

Consider the example:

(@) [ذَهَابُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd's going]{.trans}  

The noun
[ذَهَاب]{.ar}
[going]{.trans}
is the ;masdar; of the verb
[ذَهَبَ يَذْهَبُ]{.ar}
[to go]{.trans}.

Like the verb
[ذَهَبَ يَذْهَبُ]{.ar},
the ;masdar;
[ذَهَاب]{.ar}
signifies the action
of going.
But unlike the verb,
the ;masdar; does not include tense.
So it doesn't say when the action of going happened or will happen.

The ;masdar; 
is classified as a ;jamid; noun,
not a ;mushtaqq; noun.
In other words, in terms of grammatical theory,
it is not considered to be derived from the verb.
(Rather, the verb is considered to be derived from the ;masdar;.)


Also the ;masdar; is not a ;sifah;.
Technically,
this would put it in the category of ;subst;s.
But because the ;masdar; signifies the action of a verb, and not an actual entity,
it is an abstract ;subst;, not a concrete ;subst;.
In fact, we will treat it in a category of its own.
We will see, ;ia;,
that the ;masdar; can cross over to a concrete ;subst; and then refer to an entity.

But because the ;masdar; is a special noun that signifies the action of a verb, and not really an entity,

## The ;masdar; as a verb-like governor in an ;idaafah;

As a noun which is related to a verb, a ;masdar; can govern in a verb-like manner.
Let's start with a sentence which has a verb:

(@) [يسرني أن تأتي]{.ar}
<!--
(@) [أرجو أن يعتدلَ الجو]{.ar}
    [[nahw_wadih 1/54](https://shamela.ws/book/10018/48)]{.citex}  
    [I hope that the weather becomes moderate]{.trans}  
-->


;an; in the above example is that ;masdar;i ;an;.
This means that,
as we learned in chapter\ (ref),
it and its following verb
can be interpreted as a ;masdar; construction, thus:

<!--
(@) [أرجو اعتدال الجو]{.ar}
    [I hope [for] the weather's moderateness]{.trans}  
-->
(@) [يسرني إتيانك]{.ar}

We also learned that this interpretation of the
;masdar;i ;an; clause
in example () above
allows us to grammatically model the ;an; clause as one structural element.
In example () above the ;masdar; construction
[إتيانك]{.ar} is  modeled as the ;faa3il; of the verb [يسر]{.ar}.


<!--
([اعتدال]{.ar} in example () above is in the ;astate; as the ;maful; of the verb [أرجو]{.ar}.)
-->

But example () is also a legitimate sentence in its own right.
The ;masdar; [إتيان]{.ar} signifies the occurrence of the verb
[أتى يأتي]{.ar}.
But unlike the verb, it does not indicate tense.
If we had started with a ;madi; verb, for example:

(@) [يسرني أن أتيت]{.ar}

then it would have the same modeled ;masdar;:

(@) [يسرني إتيانك]{.ar}

In order to add tense to sentence with ;masdar;,
we would have to use other means, for example, an adverb:

(@) [يسرني إتيانك غدا]{.ar}

(@) [يسرني إتيانك أمس]{.ar}

In example () above,
the
;masdar; [إتيان]{.ar}
is a ;mudaf; in an ;idaafah;.
Syntactically,
the pronoun [ك]{.ar}
is in the ;istate; as the ;mudafil; in the ;idaafah;,
but semantically, it is considered the ;faa3il; of the.
;masdar; [إتيان]{.ar}.

In example () above
the verb
[تأتي]{.ar}
was used without a ;mafulb;.
Let's see what happens when we add a ;mafulb;.
For example:

(@) [يسرني أن تأتيني]{.ar}

In example () above,
the pronoun [ي]{.ar} [me]{.ar}
is the ;mafulb; of the verb
[تأتي]{.ar}.
If we model the ;an; clause in example () above as a ;masdar; construction,
then we will get:

(@) [يسرني إتيانك إِيَّايَ]{.ar}

Now, the pronoun [ك]{.ar} [your]{.trans} is again the syntactic ;mudafil; and the semantic ;faa3il;
of the
;masdar; [إتيان]{.ar}.
But the ;masdar; now also has a ;mafulb;
[إِيَايَ]{.ar} in the ;astate;.

#### The ;masdar; in an ;idaafah; governing a ;ustate; ;faa3il; {.unnumbered}

Here is another example of a ;masdar; governing a semantic
;faa3il; and a ;mafulb;:

(@) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ شُرْبِ زَيْدٍ الْعَسَلَ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/102](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/780)]{.citex}  

But this is not the only word order which is possible.
We can flip the order of the ;faa3il; and the ;mafulb;, thus:

(@) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ شُرْبِ الْعَسَلِ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/102](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/780)]{.citex}  

Now the semantic ;mafulb; 
[العسل]{.ar}
is the ;mudafil; in the ;istate;
and the ;faa3il; [زيد]{.ar} is in the ;ustate;.

This word order of
the ;mafulb;'s being the ;mudafil; and the ;faa3il; occurring after it in the ;ustate;
([شُرْبِ الْعَسَلِ زَيْدٌ]{.ar})
is not as usual as the usual word order
([شُرْبِ الْعَسَلِ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}).^[@wright@ 2/59B]
Nevertheless, it is common enough.^[[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/103](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/781#p1)]

#### The ;masdar; in an ;idaafah; governing only a ;mafulb; without a ;faa3il; {.unnumbered}

The ;faa3il; of the ;masdar; need not be mentioned.
In this case, the ;masdar; is a ;mudaf; noun to its sementic ;mafulb; directly.
For example:

(@) [مَنَعَهُمْ مِنْ قَوْلِ الْحَقِّ]{.ar}
    [@wright@ 2/57C]{.citex}  
    [He hindered them from saying the truth.]{.trans}  

Sometimes, context would be needed to tell whether the ;mudafil; is the semantic ;faa3il; or the sementic ;mafulb;.
For example:

(@) [عجبت من ضرب زيد]{.ar}
    [[@abu_hayyan_tadhyeel@ 11/70](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3605#p1)]{.citex}  

In example () above,
[زيد]{.ar} may either have been the person who did the beating or the person who was beaten.^[[@abu_hayyan_tadhyeel@ 11/70](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3605#p1)]
Context would be needed to disambiguate.

#### The ;masdar; governing a ;naib; ;faa3il; {.unnumbered}

Just like the ;masdar; can govern a ;faa3il; in the ;ustate;
it can similarly govern a ;naib; ;faa3il;.
For example:

(@) [سَرَّنِي إِعْطَاءُ الدَّنَانِيرِ **الْفَقِيرُ**]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_malik_sharh_tasheel@ 3/109](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/925)]{.citex}  
    [The giving of the [dInAr]{.trn2}s to the poor-one made me happy.]{.trans}  

#### The ;masdar; governing multiple ;mafulb;s {.unnumbered}

The ;masdar; can govern multiple ;mafulb;s just like its verb.
For example:

(@) [عَرَفْتُ إِعْطَاءَكَ الْفَقِيرَ دِرْهَمًا]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_malik_sharh_tasheel@ 3/109](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/925)]{.citex}  

(@) [عَرَفْتُ إِعْلَامَكَ خَالِدًا جَعْفَرًا مُقِيمًا]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_malik_sharh_tasheel@ 3/109](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/925)]{.citex}  

#### The ;masdar; in a ;idaafah; to an ;dharf;

The ;dharf;, like a ;mafulb, is considered a ;maful;.
As such, it can be a ;mudafil; to a governing ;masdar;.
Any ;faa3il; and/or ;mafulb;s will then occur after it in their respective syntactic states.
For example:

(@) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ ضَرْبِ **اليَوْمِ** زَيْدٌ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/103](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/781#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at today's beating [by] Zayd [to] [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}  

#### A ;na3t; to a governing ;masdar; in an ;idaafah; {.unnumbered}

A ;masdar; which is governing a governee (like a ;faa3il; or a ;mafulb;)
can be described by a ;na3t;,
but that ;na3t; should occur after the ;masdar;'s governees.^[[@ibn_malik_sharh_tasheel@ 3/108](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/924#p1); @nahw_arabi@ 2/188]
For example,
we should not say:

(@) ;x; [عرفت سوقك **العنيف** الإبل]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_malik_sharh_tasheel@ 3/108](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/924#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew your harsh driving of the camels]{.trans}  

We should say instead:

(@) [عرفت سوقك الإبل **العنيف**]{.ar}

#### A ;na3t; to the governee of a ;masdar; in an ;idaafah; {.unnumbered}

When the ;masdar; is governing a ;faa3il; or a ;mafulb; in an ;idaafah;,
and that governee is to be described by a ;na3t;,
then the ;na3t; may,
optionally,
be either in the ;istate;,
or in the ;ustate; for the ;faa3il; and the ;astate; for the ;mafulb;.^[@nahw_arabi@ 2/189; [@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/104--105](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/782#p1); @wright@ 2/59C]
So we can say:

(@) [عجبت من شرب زيد الظريف والظريف]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/104](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/782#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ أَكْلِ الطَّعَامِ الْحَارِّ/الْحَارَّ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 2/189]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at the eating of the hot food [by] Zayd]{.trans}  

#### A ;3atf; to the governee of a ;masdar; in an ;idaafah; {.unnumbered}

When the ;masdar; is governing a ;faa3il; or a ;mafulb; in an ;idaafah;,
and that governee is followed by a ;3atf; and ;ma3toof;,
then the ;ma3toof; may,
optionally,
be either in the ;istate;,
or in the ;ustate; for the ;faa3il; and the ;astate; for the ;mafulb;.^[@nahw_arabi@ 2/189; @wright@ 2/57D-58A]
So we can say:

(@) [سَاءَنِي إِهْمَالُ سَعِيدٍ وَخَالِدٍ/خَالِدٌ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 2/189]{.citex}  

(@) [كَرِهْتُ أَكْلَ الْخُبْزِ وَاللَّحْمِ/اللَّحْمَ]{.ar}
    [@wright@ 2/58A]{.citex}  
    [I disliked eating the bread and the meat.]{.trans}  

(@) [سَاءَنِي ضَرْبُ خَالِدٍ وَسَعِيدٍ/سَعِيدًا خَلِيلٌ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 2/189]{.citex}  

## The ;tanwin;ed ;masdar; as a verb-like governor

In section\ (ref) above,
we have seen how the ;masdar; governing in an ;idaafah;.
However, an ;idaafah; is not the only form in which a ;masdar; can govern in a verb-like manner.
A ;masdar; can also govern when it is ;tanwin;ed.
For example:

(@masdar_darbin_zaydan) [عَجِبتُ مِن ضَرْبٍ زيدا]{.ar}
    [[@sibawayhi@ 1/189](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/187); [@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]{.citex}

(@masdar_darbin_zaydan_bakrun) [عجبتُ مِن ضَرْبٍ زيداً بكرٌ]{.ar}
    [[@sibawayhi@ 1/189](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/187)]{.citex}

(@masdar_darbin_zaydun_3amran) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ ضَرْبٍ زَيْدٌ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
    [modified from [@sibawayhi@ 1/189](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/187); @wright@ 2/59A]{.citex}

(@) [أَوۡ إِطۡعَـٰمࣱ فِی یَوۡمࣲ ذِی مَسۡغَبَةࣲ ۝١٤ یَتِیمࣰا ذَا مَقۡرَبَةٍ ۝١٥]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/90/14-15@, cited by [@ibn_malik_sharh_tasheel@ 3/115](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/931#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Or feeding on a day of severe hunger An orphan of near relationship]{.trans}  

(@) [بضرب بالسيوف رؤوس قوم]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1); @wright@ 2/57C]{.citex}  
    [by striking, with the swords, the heads of a people]{.trans}  


The ;tanwin;ed ;masdar; governing a ;faa3il; and a ;mafulb; is comparatively rarer
than the ;masdar; governing in a ;idaafah;.^[@wright@ 2/59B; [@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]
Some grammarians mandate that when a ;tanwin;ed ;masdar; is a governor then its ;faa3il; should not be mentioned after it.^[[@abu_hayyan_tadhyeel@ 11/75](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3610)]
So they would allow example
(@masdar_darbin_zaydan) above but not examples (@masdar_darbin_zaydan_bakrun) and (@masdar_darbin_zaydun_3amran).

## The ;masdar; prefixed by [ال]{.ar} as a verb-like governor

In addition to the ;masdar; governing in an ;idaafah; and when ;tanwin;ed,
the ;masdar; can also govern when it is prefixed by [ال]{.ar}.
This is the rarest out of the three formations.^[[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]

(@) [عجبت من الضرب زيدا]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]{.citex}  

(@) [ضَعِيفُ النِّكَايَةِ أَعْدَاءَهُ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_malik_sharh_tasheel@ 3/116](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/932#p1); @wright@ 2/57D]{.citex}  
    [weak in harming his enemies]{.trans}

(@) [فلم أنكُلْ عن الضَّرْبِ مسْمِعا]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_malik_sharh_tasheel@ 3/116](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/932#p1); @wright@ 2/57D]{.citex}  
    [and I did not desist from beating [#mismae]{.trn2}]{.trans}  

## The ;masdar; as a verb-like governor compared to the ;ism_fail;

We have already seen, in chapter\ (ref),
that the ;ism_fail; is also
a noun that is related to a verb, and that can govern in a verb-like manner.
But the ;masdar; and the ;ism_fail; are different in how they govern a ;faa3il; and a ;mafulb;.

Firstly, the ;masdar; is a ;jamid; noun.
So it does not govern a
;mustatir; ;faa3il; pronoun.
When the ;masdar; is governing a ;mafulb; without a ;faa3il;
as in example ()
[مَنَعَهُمْ مِنْ قَوْلِ الْحَقِّ]{.ar}
then, no ;mustatir; ;faa3il; pronoun is ;taqdir;ed.

Secondly, when the ;masdar; is governing in an ;idaafah;,
(for example
[عَجِبْتُ مِنْ ضَرْبِ زَيْدٍ عَمْرًا]{.ar})
then this ;idaafah; is ;ma3nawi;, not ;lafzi;.^[@haazimi@ 71/9]
However, when the ;ism_fail; is governing in an ;idaafah;, then the ;idaafah; is ;lafzi; (see section\ (ref)).

Thirdly, the ;ism_fail; not prefixed by [ال]{.ar} only governs in a verb-like manner
when it has an imperfective meaning.
The ;masdar; on the other hand can govern for both a perfective and imperfective meaning.
For example:

(@) [عجبت من ضربك زيدا أمس/غدا/الآن]{.ar}
    [modified from [@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]{.citex}  

The ;masdar; as a verb-like governor
does have one similarity to the governing ;ism_fail;.
And that is that both their ;faa3il;s are not the
;musnadi; of a new sentence.
So, for example, in the sentence:

(@) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ شُرْبِ الْعَسَلِ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/102](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/780)]{.citex}  


the ;faa3il; [زَيْد]{.ar} does not form an inner sentence with the ;masdar; [شُرْب]{.ar}.
Rather, the ;masdar;
[شُرْب]{.ar},
as a single-word element, is in the ;istate;, governed by the preposition [مِنْ]{.ar}.

An exception to the ;faa3il; of a ;masdar; not being a ;musnadi;,
and also to the ;masdar; not governing a ;mustatir; ;faa3il; pronoun,
is when the ;masdar; occurs as the ;naib; to a verb.
For example:

(@) [ضربا زيدا]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/93](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/771)]{.citex}  
    [Hit Zayd!]{.trans}  

The ;masdar; as a ;naib; to a verb will be covered in more detail in section\ (mmutlaq), ;ia;.

## An intervening word in the ;idaafah;

## The ;ism_masdar;

The ;ism_masdar; is a concrete ;subst; that crosses over to be used like a ;masdar;.
Examples:

| ;ism_masdar; | verb | actual ;masdar; |
|:----|:-----|:--|
|[سَلَام]{.ar} [peace]{.trans}  |[سَلَّمَ يُسَلِّمُ]{.ar}  [to say]{.trans} [السَّلَامُ عَلَيْكُمْ]{.ar} ([عَلَى]{.ar} to s.o.) |[تَسْلِيم]{.ar} |
|[عَطَاء]{.ar} [gift]{.trans}   |[أَعْطَى يُعْطِي]{.ar} [to give]{.trans} |[إِعْطَاء]{.ar} |
|[كَلَام]{.ar} [speech]{.trans} |[كَلَّمَ يُكَلِّمُ]{.ar}  [to speak]{.trans} [(to]{.trans} [ه]{.ar} [s.o.)]{.trans} |[تَكْلِيم]{.ar} |
|[كَلَام]{.ar} [speech]{.trans} |[تَكَلَّمَ يَتَكَلَّمُ]{.ar}  [to speak]{.trans} |[تَكَلُّم]{.ar} |
|[قُبْلَة]{.ar} [kiss]{.trans} |[قَبَّلَ يُقَبِّلُ]{.ar}  [to kiss (]{.trans} [ه]{.ar} [s.o.)]{.trans}|[تَقْبِيل]{.ar} |
|[عَذَاب]{.ar} [punishment]{.trans} |[عَذَّبَ يُعَذِّبُ]{.ar}  [to punish ([ه]{.ar} s.o.)]{.trans}|[تَعْذِيب]{.ar} |
|[حِمْل]{.ar} [load]{.trans} |[حَمَلَ يَحْمِلُ]{.ar}  [to carry ([هـ]{.ar} s.th.)]{.trans}|[حَمْل]{.ar} |
|[عِشْرَة]{.ar} [association]{.trans} |[عَاشَرَ يُعَاشِرُ]{.ar}  [to consort (with [ه]{.ar} s.o.)]{.trans}|[مُعَاشَرَة]{.ar} |

The ;ism_masdar; originally signifies the meaning of a concrete ;subst;.^[[@maani_nahw@ 3/164--167](https://shamela.ws/book/17801/889)]
So, for example
the ;masdar; [تَكْلِيم]{.ar} signifies the action of speaking to someone,
and the ;ism_masdar; [كَلَام]{.ar} signifies the concrete ;subst; [speech]{.trans}.
But the ;ism_masdar;, once it crosses over to a ;masdar;,
can signify the action of the verb, just like the actual ;masdar;.
As such, it can even govern in a verb-like manner.^[[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/101](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/779#p1)]
So we can say:

(@) [**بِعِشْرَتِكَ الْكِرَامَ** تُعَدُّ مِنْهُمْ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/100](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/778#p1)]{.citex}  
    [By your associating with the generous-ones you will be reckoned [as one] amongst them.]{.trans}  
    ([الْكِرَام]{.ar} is in the ;astate; as the ;mafulb; of the ;ism_masdar; [عِشْرَة]{.ar}.)  

(@) [وَبَعْدَ عَطَائِكَ الْمِائَةَ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 3/99](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/777#p1)]{.citex}  
    [And after your giving of the one hundred (camels)]{.trans}  
    ([الْمِائَة]{.ar} is in the ;astate; as the ;mafulb; of the ;ism_masdar; [عَطَاء]{.ar}.)  

(@) [قَالُوا كَلَامُكَ هِنْدًا وَهِيَ مُصْغِيَةٌ يَشْفِيكَ]{.ar}
    [[@sabban@ 2/435](https://shamela.ws/book/11539/865)]{.citex}  
    [They said "Your speaking to Hind while she is giving ear will cure you."]{.trans}  
    ([هِنْد]{.ar} is in the ;astate; as the ;mafulb; of the ;ism_masdar; [كَلَام]{.ar}.)

وَقَوله عَلَيْهِ الصَّلَاة وَالسَّلَام وَحج الْبَيْت من اسْتَطَاعَ إِلَيْهِ سَبِيلا وَبَيت الْكتاب أَي كتاب سِيبَوَيْهٍ وَهُوَ قَول الشَّاعِر تنفى يداها الْحَصَى فِي كل هاجرة نفي الدراهيم تنقاد الصياريف
الثَّانِي الْمنون وإعماله أَقيس من إِعْمَال الْمُضَاف لِأَنَّهُ يشبه الْفِعْل بالتنكير كَقَوْلِه تَعَالَى أَو إطْعَام فِي يَوْم ذِي مسغبة يَتِيما تَقْدِيره أَو أَن يطعم فِي يَوْم ذِي مسغبة يَتِيما الثَّالِث الْمُعَرّف بأل وإعماله شَاذ قِيَاسا واستعمالا كَقَوْلِه عجبت من الرزق الْمُسِيء إلهه وَمن ترك بعض الصَّالِحين فَقِيرا أَي عجبت من أَن رزق الْمُسِيء إلهه وَمن أَن ترك بعض الصَّالِحين فَقِيرا
:::

### When ;masdar; has ;tanwin; then its ;faa3il; should not be mentioned

<https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3610>

::: {.ar}
والذي يظهر لي مذهب الفراء؛ لأن كل ما أورد س وغيره من المصدر المنون في لسان العرب لم يذكر بعده فاعل، ولم يذكره س إلا في نفس عبارته، قال: "وذلك عجبت من ضرب زيد عمراً"، وليس في لفظه ما يدل على أنه محكي عن العرب، فيحتمل أن يكون ذلك رأياً منه، بل هو ظاهر كلامه وقياس منه؛ لأنه قال: "لأنك كما تقول: عجبت من أن ضرب زيد عمراً ينبغي أن تقول: عجبت من ضرب زيد عمراً". وكأن س لم ير مانعاً يمنع من ذلك إذ نزل منزلة: أن يفعل، والفاعل يظهر مع أن يفعل، فينبغي أن يظهر مع ما نزل منزلته، وكونه يذكر مضافاً إليه المصدر يقضي بذكره معه غير مضاف إذ لا فرق.

والذي ينبغي أن يعول عليه مذهب الفراء؛ لأنه سامع لغة من العرب، وقد نفى ذلك عن لسانهم، مع أن الكوفيين أوسع سماعاً وأتبع لشواذ كلام العرب من البصريين.
:::

### idafa is real or fake?

<https://shamela.ws/book/36130/1365>

---

::: {.ar}
تقول: عجبت من ضرب زيدٍ عمراً، إذا كان زيدٌ فاعلاً، ومن ضرب عمرو زيدٌ فتضيفه إلى المفعول إن شئت، إلا أن إضافته - إلى أي الاسمين أضفته - إضافة حقيقية إذ كان اسم جنسٍ كغيره من الأجناس، وإضافة اسم الفاعل المعمل إلى معموله إضافةٌ غير حقيقية لأنها في تقدير الانفصال، والمصدر يتخصص بالإضافة أو يتعرف إن كان مضافاً إلى معرفةٍ، واسم الفاعل ليس كذلك، والمصدر يضاف إلى مرفوعه ومنصوبه، أي ذلك أردت صح فيه، واسم الفاعل إنما يضاف إلى منصوبه لا إلى مرفوعه، لأن مرفوعه هو هو في المعنى ومسماه مسماه. 
:::
